metadata.case_name: Ramagya Prasad Gupta & Anr. v. Murli Prasad & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 1710 of 1967 and 1986 of 1968

facts.text: Mahendra Prasad obtained licence for electrification of Chhapra town in 1932, assigned to Janardhan Prasad Varma after Mahendra's death in 1936, then to Chhapra Electric Supply Co. Ltd., which went into voluntary liquidation in 1944.
Liquidator decided to sell electricity undertaking by public auction and assign licence to purchaser with Government sanction.

Before auction, Ayodhya Prasad, Murli Prasad (respondent No.1), Parasnath Prasad, Gurbharan Shah, and Nandkishore Prasad entered oral partnership agreement to purchase in Murli Prasad's name: shares Ayodhya 8 annas, Murli 4 annas, Parasnath 2 annas, Gurbharan and Nandkishore 1 anna each; licence in Murli's name alone, contributions proportional.

Undertaking sold to Murli Prasad on September 15, 1944 for Rs. 4,10,000 (highest bid); partners contributed proportionally: Ayodhya Rs. 2,05,000, Murli Rs. 1,02,500, Parasnath Rs. 51,250, Gurbharan Rs. 25,625, Nandkishore Rs. 25,625.
Payments to liquidator in three instalments; before last instalment of Rs. 2,50,000 on July 13, 1945, oral agreement incorporated into registered partnership deed on July 10, 1945 (Ext. G).
Nandkishore Prasad retired, share taken by Gurbharan Shah.

In 1950, Rs. 1,50,000 required for new plant/machinery; Murli and Parasnath unable to contribute proportionally, sold 1 anna each to Ayodhya; Ayodhya's share to 10 annas, Murli to 3 annas, Parasnath to 1 anna; second registered partnership deed on August 31, 1950 (Ext. 9); partnership dissolved May 13, 1953 (Ext. C.I).

Ayodhya Prasad and Murli Prasad as Karta of joint families; shares divided among family members: Murli's 3 annas (Murli and Dharindhar 1 anna each, sons Chandreshwar and Kamleshwar 6 pies each); Ayodhya's 10 annas (Ayodhya and Ram Sharan 3 annas 9 pies each, Ram Sharan's sons Brahmadev 1 anna 3 pies, Ramagya 1 anna 3 pies? text cut); Parasnath 1 anna, Gurbharan 2 annas.

Electrical Inspector informed Murli licence partnership illegal under Indian Electricity Act; Government cancelled licence; Murli attempted forcible possession, proceedings under s.144 CrPC decided in favour of Ramagya Prasad Gupta et al. on April 14, 1954.

Parasnath Prasad (Murli's son-in-law) filed Title Suit No.68/1954 on May 28, 1954 for declaration of partnership dissolution by notice, accounts from Ramagya Prasad Gupta et al.; during pendency, Government revoked licence under s.4(1) Electricity Act, powers/liabilities determined under s.5(1)a; receiver appointed (Additional District Magistrate).
Receiver took possession; Government purchased undertaking October 20, 1955, deposited Rs.3,00,000 in court as part purchase money.
Murli Prasad filed Title Suit No.94/1956 on November 5, 1956 declaring him sole licensee/owner entitled to entire purchase price; alleged he paid all money, others employees, partnership illegal.
Nandkishore Prasad filed Suit No.113/1957 on September 21, 1957 claiming still partner with 1 anna share.
Three suits consolidated, tried by 5th Additional Subordinate Judge, Chhapra; decreed Parasnath's 68/54, dismissed 94/56 and 113/57 on February 10, 1959.

Murli filed FA 160/59 (from 94/56) and 161/59 (from 68/54); Nandkishore FA 154/59 withdrawn; High Court reversed trial court in FA 160/59, declared Murli sole entitled to money, based on illegal partnership.
Ramagya Prasad Gupta filed CA 1710/67 (from FA 160/59) and 1711/67 (from FA 161/59); Brahmadeo Prasad filed CA 1986/68 (FA 160/59) and 1985/68 (FA 161/59).
Kuldip Narain, Jagdish Narain, Kedar Nath Sah added as defendants 12-14 in 68/54 as Parasnath family members.
Jagdish Narain (defendant 13) died; LRs not brought on record; CA 1711/67 and 1985/68 abated/dismissed.
Prior Supreme Court in Ramagya Prasad Gupta v. Murli Prasad held appeals abated wholly (majority).

legal_issues.text: Whether appeals barred by res judicata u/s 11 CPC or general principles due to abatement of appeals from Title Suit 68/54.
Whether subject-matter and issues in Title Suit 68/54 and 94/56 same for res judicata.
Whether partnership illegal/void under Indian Electricity Act, and if so, whether partners entitled to share in compensation money contributed to purchase.
Whether Murli Prasad sole contributor to purchase money or partners contributed proportionally.
Entitlement to compensation money deposited by Government after purchase of undertaking.
Applicability of s.65 Contract Act to recover contributions if agreement void.

petitioner_arguments.text: Subject-matter of Suit 94/56 different from 68/54: 68/54 for dissolution/accounts during subsistence of licence/undertaking; 94/56 post-revocation/purchase, re: entitlement to compensation based on contributions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: No res judicata as different subject-matter, parties (def 12-14 not in 94/56)

petitioner_arguments.text: Oral partnership pre-auction, contributions proven by receipts, deeds (Ext G,9), bank records, balance sheets sent to partners/Govt; Murli admitted discussions/shares.
Even if partnership illegal, partners entitled to recover contributions u/s 65 Contract Act or as assets u/s 14 Partnership Act converted to compensation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Contract Act s.65; Partnership Act s.14; not barred by limitation

petitioner_arguments.text: No knowledge of illegality till Govt notification 1955; balance sheets openly sent to Govt.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Electricity Act ss.9(2)(3) not making inter-partner claims non-adjudicable

respondent_arguments.text: Appeals barred by res judicata u/s 11 CPC as common issues (partnership validity) directly/substantially in issue in both consolidated suits, same parties affected.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: CPC s.11; general res judicata principles

respondent_arguments.text: Paid entire purchase money alone; partnership illegal/void under Electricity Act (no Govt consent for assignment to partnership); others mere lenders, claims barred by limitation (s.65 Contract, Art.62 Limitation).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Electricity Act; Contract Act s.65

respondent_arguments.text: Induced fraudulently into partnership deeds; sole licensee entitled to entire compensation.

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary objection overruled: subject-matter different (94/56 re: sole entitlement to compensation post-revocation vs 68/54 dissolution/accounts); surviving issues in 94/56 (4,9,12); parties not identical.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Issue of sole entitlement to compensation not in 68/54

court_reasoning.text: Murli's claim he paid entire money dishonest; evidence (receipts Ext F-1, bank ledgers Ext M/M-1, admissions in cross-exam, proceedings Ext E-1/R-1, balance sheets Ext X-1) proves pre-auction oral partnership, proportional contributions, registered deeds.
Partners unaware of illegality till 1955 notification; openly sent balance sheets to Govt; no bar to adjudicate inter se claims even if partnership invalid under Electricity Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Electricity Act ss.9(2)(3) not affecting partner rights to assets/contributions

court_reasoning.text: Contributions became partnership assets u/s 14 Partnership Act; now compensation money; recoverable u/s 65 Contract Act even if void (discovery of voidness).
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.65 applies to ab initio void agreements upon discovery; supported by Hyderabad FB

court_reasoning.text: No need for s.70 Contract or Specific Relief ss.39/41; suits not barred by limitation.

holdings.text: No res judicata bar as different subject-matters.
Partnership existed, contributions proportional; even if illegal, partners entitled to share compensation per 1950 deed shares.
Murli Prasad not sole entitled; partners/legal reps/assignees share compensation after liabilities.
s.65 Contract Act entitles recovery of advantage received under void agreement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramagya Prasad Gupta v. Murli Prasad

precedents_cited.relevance: One trial/one decision, no res judicata if one appeal time-barred
No two appeals needed for one trial/finding/decision

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheodan Singh v. Mst. Daryao Kaur
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata where common issues in prior dismissed appeals

precedents_cited.case_name: Budhu Lal v. Deccan Banking Company Ltd
precedents_cited.relevance: s.65 Contract applies to recover money under void agreements ab initio

precedents_cited.case_name: Harnath Kaur v. Inder Bahadur Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Agreements discovered void include ab initio void

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity Act, 1910
statutes_cited.relevance: Revocation of licence, purchase of undertaking; no consent for assignment voids transfer but not inter se partner claims

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Restoration of advantage under void agreement discovered void

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Res judicata bar not applicable due to different subject-matter

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment/decree reversed; Title Suit No.94/1956 dismissed with costs; Murli Prasad not entitled solely to compensation; partners/legal reps/assignees per 1950 deed entitled to share compensation after deducting liabilities of Chhapra Electric Supply Works.
outcome.relief_granted: Share in compensation proportional to shares in deed dated August 31, 1950

key_quotes.text: "The case of the first respondent that he paid the entire money for the purchase of the undertaking is, in our view, a dishonest plea."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Murli's core claim based on evidence

key_quotes.text: "Even if the partnership was illegal and void as contended by the respondent in the other title suit, the same question, namely, whether the plaintiff first respondent alone would be entitled to the entire compensation, was not the subject-matter of the Title Suit No. 68 of 1954."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Section 65 of the Contract Act will readily come to the rescue of the partners."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for recovery despite potential invalidity
